186010164.review:
Aby uczcić wbicie 2k godzin gry na Steamie (wcześniej grałam bezpośrednio przez launcher bez pośrednictwa Steama, więc pewnie łącznie będzie około 3k godzin), postanowiłam napisać podsumowanie gry, w której spędziłam do tej pory najwięcej czasu, co jest już pewnie  recenzją samą w sobie 😊
___

Elder Scrolls Online to tytuł, który wciąga nie tylko przez swoją epicką fabułę, ale również przez ogromny, żyjący świat Tamriel, pełen tajemnic, wyzwań i, co najważniejsze, społecznych interakcji. Gra łączy klasyczne elementy RPG z rozbudowanym systemem MMORPG, oferując graczom niezliczoną liczbę godzin zabawy.  

-PLUSY- 
✅ - Bogaty świat Tamriel - Od ośnieżonych szczytów Skyrim po gorące pustynie Elsweyr, czy też wypełnione polami słoneczników słoneczne High Isle, każdy region oferuje unikalny klimat i historię. Gra jest nie tylko piękna, ale także głęboka, z każdym zakątkiem pełnym detali.  

✅ - Społeczność i gildie - ESO to coś więcej niż tylko gra – to społeczność. Gildie w tej grze są kluczowe, oferując przestrzeń do współpracy, wzajemnej pomocy i organizowania wspólnych aktywności. Wiele gildii jest aktywnych, organizując eventy, rajdy i zadania, co stwarza przyjazne środowisko do wspólnej zabawy.  

✅ - Elastyczność rozgrywki - Twój bohater to naprawdę twoje dzieło – wybór rasy, klasy i stylu gry sprawia, że każda postać jest unikalna. Możesz zostać potężnym czarodziejem, wytrzymałym wojownikiem czy zwinny złodziejem, co daje mnóstwo możliwości w trakcie gry.  Od Ciebie również zależy, jaką będziesz pełnić rolę w drużynie: tank, DPS czy healer, niezależnie od klasy, którą grasz. 

✅ - System housingu - Elder Scrolls Online wprowadza naprawdę głęboki system housingu, który pozwala graczom stworzyć swoje własne miejsce w Tamriel. Od skromnych pokoików w karczmie, po olbrzymie rezydencje – możesz udekorować swój dom tak, jak tylko chcesz. Bogaty wybór mebli, dekoracji i przedmiotów pozwala na pełną personalizację. Co ważne, domy są dostępne zarówno dla nowych graczy, jak i dla tych, którzy spędzili już setki godzin w grze. Możesz zapraszać innych graczy, by odwiedzili twój dom, a także organizować w nim wydarzenia czy spotkania. To świetny sposób na odpoczynek od epickich przygód i stworzenie swojego osobistego zakątka w grze.  

✅ - Fabuła i zadania - Główna linia fabularna wciąga, ale to zadania poboczne często oferują najciekawsze historie i pozwalają zgłębić tajemnice świata. Misje są dobrze napisane, często z wyborami, które mają realny wpływ na wydarzenia.  

- MINUSY -
❌ - Subskrypcja ESO Plus - Choć gra oferuje sporo za darmo, subskrypcja ESO Plus daje znaczną przewagę, np. w postaci dostępu do wszystkich dodatków i wygodniejszych opcji magazynowania. Niektórym graczom może to przeszkadzać.  

❌ - Grind w endgame - Po przejściu głównej fabuły i osiągnięciu wysokiego poziomu, może się pojawić poczucie monotonii, zwłaszcza gdy chodzi o zbieranie lepszego sprzętu czy rozwój postaci w końcowej fazie gry.  

❌ - Interfejs - Początkowo interfejs może wydawać się skomplikowany, zwłaszcza dla nowych graczy, którzy mogą poczuć się przytłoczeni liczbą opcji.  

PODSUMOWUJĄC:
Elder Scrolls Online to gra, która nie tylko oferuje ogromny, żyjący świat i fantastyczne przygody, ale również daje graczom swobodę w tworzeniu swojej własnej przestrzeni w Tamriel. System housingu, który pozwala na personalizację swoich domów, to fantastyczny sposób na odpoczynek i wyrażenie siebie w grze. Jeśli szukasz tytułu, w którym możesz odkrywać, walczyć, tworzyć i integrować się z innymi graczami – ESO to propozycja, której warto dać szansę.

186006742.review:
Pros:
* Basically skyrim or oblivion but an MMO
(A lot of people forget how basic the premise of those titles were w/ nostalgia tinted glasses. The questing loop was just as shallow as here, and the open world full of odd locales and quests is even larger in this title. The only thing that falls short is AI relationship systems, frequent lasting consequences, and non-mmo combat.)
* Elder-scrolls nostalgia
* A large variety of abilities to build-craft from.
* Player housing.

* Overland and standard bosses are the definition of trivially easy, you will never struggle doing a quest fight.
* Dungeons, including veteran are trivially easy to the point where half of your runs are sprinting past ads to the boss. 
(Several times as tank i've had the issue where my passive regen outpaced vet boss damage, not letting us wipe the run for scroll.)
* Arenas & Trials (Dungeons but harder) are overhyped, same thing but you need to stand/hit the right places.
(I nearly solo'd vDSA)
* PvP is the lowest pop its ever been with almost zero reward. 
(Imperial City nearly dead this weekend, apart from the occasional roaming duo or backcapping rogue.)
* A large portion of the content is now locked behind DLCs at absurd pricing.
(My friend wants to replicate one of my builds, but I am sad to tell him he'd need to buy like 6 different DLCs for the items and skills. They're generally $20-$30 apart from the scarce mini-bundle.)
* Combat is optimized to hell and back.
(it is an mmo, this is a numbers game- and the longtime playerbase has gotten really good at it. In PvP you will not be able to compete without much, much preparation.)

186001552.review:
This game is an MMO, and Bethesda didn't make it, do not expect a traditional modern Elder Scrolls experience from this game, you will be super disappointed if you do.

This game isn't super unique, it's quite literally just an MMORPG with Elder Scrolls flair to it, and I don't think I would like it if it wasn't Elder Scrolls, it translates every typical mechanic and trope from MMORPGs and fits it into the Elder Scrolls world very well. Now it might make some people upset that the mechanics of this game aren't the most lore-friendly, being that this game is the only case where we can grow spikes out of our backs, but Nirn [spoiler] canonically isn't real, [/spoiler] I say anything goes.

There are a couple of things that make your character, race, and class, race has some stat effects and its own set of passive skills you can unlock, while classes will give you exclusive skills that are both active and passive. Each class has 3 skill categories, their DPS skills, their Tank skills, and their Support skills. DPS skills do damage, duh, and apply effects onto enemies, Tank skills draw aggro and protect you from damage, and then support skills provide utility to your group, not always just healing, but still mostly healing. Then there are weapon skills which are attacks and passives exclusive to that weapon, and then there are armor skills which are just passive and improve the performance of armor, and then there's a whole load of secondary skills that are unlocked by doing certain activities and are by far the most painful to progress, especially the crafting skills. The combat-related skills can be very fun to progress as you try to figure out your playstyle and optimize your character, but the rest of them are a huge pain, they involve immense repetition and it can get very stale, very quickly, but the payoff is pretty good, having a well-made character is super fun to play with, especially in a group.

Your gear is another very important thing, there are a few ways to obtain weapons and armor: Craft it, find it, receive it as a quest reward or random drop. The gear you're gonna want is gonna belong to sets, which give you stat buffs depending on how many pieces of the set you have equipped, and based on how many stat buffs a set maxes out at, you can get about 2-3 full set bonuses when fully kitted out. You have 2 weapons, 6 armor pieces, and 3 jewelry slots (2 rings and one necklace). Pieces of a set can be obtained two ways, boss drops in dungeons and then crafting, and there is no overlap, specific sets can only be found in dungeons while the others can only be crafted at specific stations in specific parts of Tamriel, some of which require DLCs to access. But it doesn't matter how you end up getting your gear, crafting is very important. Crafting is super simple, you only need two types of items to make it, the item which determines the quality of your gear which just determines the level of your gear and then the style material which is purely cosmetic but you still need one to craft anything, just one style material per item though, so don't worry. In order to craft higher level gear you need the necessary skills unlocked in the crafting category for that specifc type of crafting, there are 7, 4 of them are for gear, the other 3 or for consumables, each takes their own materials (except style materials) and need to be leveled up separately, this can be done by crafting items that belong it that category, disassembling gear, (gear made from other players and gear with bonuses listed for disassembling will give you the most XP for it) and doing writ quests, which require you to craft some specific items for rewards, you get one per crafting category per day. You can also put secondary effects on gear, which require their own items which you find through various means, and the only way to craft gear with these effects is to destroy gear with the effect to research it, which is put on a timer, which is an exponential increase each time you do it, going up to a month, it's really not that fun. The grind for gear is probably one of the most tedious parts about it, it's not hard, just time consuming, use some add-ons if you don't want to be searching forever for crafting materials, Zenimax allows it so it's fine.

The actual gameplay is actually quite fun, you end up getting two weapon slots for double the amount of skills you can use, just push a button to swap weapons and now you have different skills to use, what I often do is have my setup skills on one weapon while all of my attacks are on another. The name of the game is use your skills effectively, most classes have a "spam skill" that you're meant to use repeatedly when you're not using something else, and some classes are built around the spam skill, like the Arcanist, where each time you use the spam skill, you generate something called crux, and some skills consume it, and they get more powerful the more crux it consumes, I really like it and I think it's super fun. The game is most fun when played with a group, dungeons are 4 players, and then Trials are 15, and Trials are my favorite, especially when they're planned well, and it feels super good to win them, its really where the MMORPG magic shines. I also don't recommend playing in first person, it might feel more like Elder Scrolls that way, but you're putting yourself at a disadvantage, you'll be losing a lot of sight that way, and the game seems built around third person despite defaulting to first.

The graphics are much more cartoony than the other Elder Scrolls games, they don't look bad necessarily, Elder Scrolls games never looked that bad when compared to games of the time, but the ESO artstyle is different, and I think it fits well.

The Soundtrack isn't super special, it's mostly just rehashes of old songs from the series, but that doesn't stop it from sounding pretty good, all Orchestral and whatnot.

The writing in this game is pretty balls, it's very clear that story was not a huge concern for Zenimax, at least not in the dialogue, I never bothered listening to it, the stories were never that engaging, some of the story moments can be really cool, be it the bossfights or the end of the main story, but overall it leaves a lot to be desired, I love good stories, games like RDR2 and Cyberpunk 2077 have some of my favorite stories and my ears were wide open and listening to all the dialogue even though the games were dozens of hours long each.

This game is not lacking in content by any means, the base game alone will give you a couple dozen hours, both by doing the main story and going through all of the zone stories, I'd recommend doing a good chunk of the Base Game before deciding on buying any DLCs.

The DLCs in this game are a bit strange, first are the chapters, these are the big DLCs and they add the most content, usually in the form of new classes and mechanics, each chapter comes with a new Trial, a new area to explore, new quests, a new story, etc. After a chapter releases, soon after we get some smaller, follow-up DLC, these will be in the form of zone and dungeon DLCs, zone DLCs add new areas with new quests and story while the Dungeon DLCs add new replayable dungeons to grind for items in, neither Zone or Dungeon DLCs add new mechanics or classes, but these follow-up DLCs are also usually continuations of the Chapter DLC's story, if you care about that at all.

This game's community is a mixed bag, there are the enjoyers, and then the complainers, you'll see the enjoyers actually playing the game and are a part of a guild to do dungeons and trials with and help their fellow players out, while the complainers usually stick to the forums to bitch about whatever complaints they have, and sure, their complaints are valid, but I often see them crapping on people just trying to enjoy the game and asking questions on the forum to get help, stay away from the forums.

185982341.review:
The Elder Scrolls Online — огромный мир, который стоит исследовать!
The Elder Scrolls Online — это не просто игра, это возможность вернуться в волшебный мир Тамриэля, но с совершенно новым опытом. Для фанатов TES здесь есть всё, за что мы любим эту серию: потрясающие локации, глубокий лор и разнообразие механик.
Что делает игру уникальной:
Мир и атмосфера. Локации невероятно проработаны, каждый уголок вызывает восторг. Тамриэль здесь оживает, и ты чувствуешь себя его частью.
Сюжет. Квесты не сводятся к банальному "принеси-подай". Истории продуманы и часто захватывают настолько, что забываешь о времени.
Разнообразие билдов. Хочешь быть вампиром-маговиком? Или танком, который наносит урон? Пожалуйста! Комбинации классов и способностей практически безграничны.
Контент. Постоянные обновления, DLC и кроссоверы делают игру свежей. Каждое новое дополнение добавляет что-то уникальное — будь то новые зоны, классы или активности.
Но есть и ложка дёгтя:
Гринд. Если хочешь стать топовым игроком или добыть редкие предметы, придётся потратить кучу времени. Местами это утомляет.
Донат и подписка. Без ESO Plus играть можно, но это усложняет жизнь: инвентарь быстро забивается, а доступ к DLC ограничен.
Интерфейс. Он перегружен и неудобен, особенно для новичков. Без модов освоиться непросто.
Итог:
ESO — это смесь приключений, стратегий и настоящего погружения в мир TES. Да, игра требует времени, иногда нервов, а иногда и денег, но эмоции, которые она дарит, стоят того. Если вы фанат серии или просто ищете качественную MMO с проработанным лором, настоятельно рекомендую попробовать. Тамриэль ждёт!

185943747.review:
头一次把一个游戏玩上上千小时，说来也巧合，是2023年4月左右游戏荒了，不知道玩什么游戏了，主要是那年我这里又是疫情管理，天天宅家里打游戏，居然把手头的游戏打光了，春促又过去了，夏促又没来，本来打算去试试《最终幻想14》的，没想到日式演出实在是太尬了，人物倒是挺可爱，玩法也不错，地图也是真漂亮，但是沙之家的剧情演绎让我尴尬的脚趾狂抠，最后还是放弃了，没想到正好这时候出现了7天免费游玩的《上古卷轴OL》！果断入坑来试试，反正免费。

这下不得了，一玩就上瘾！毕竟我也是B社的老玩家了，上古卷轴345，辐射34+新维加斯全都有。这熟悉的B社味道让我太舒服了（不用你说，我当然知道是ZOS做的！）。弥补了我没有玩过魔兽等大型网游的遗憾，让我体验了从新人成长成为大佬，成为团长的艰辛与快乐，没想到有一天我也会指挥大家来打团，真的是有新体验了。团员总说我有口音，我寻思我普通话说的挺好的啊！

如果你是老滚玩家，一定不要错过，本游戏是支持完全单人模式的，是完全可以没有社交的，就是看剧情，反正老滚的核心也就是看剧情和瞎搞。社交也挺不错的，交点新朋友，网游特色嘛。也算在我人生中留下了浓墨重彩的一笔，了结了没玩过大型网游的遗憾，我之前还寻思要不要去玩玩魔兽呢，结果我还接收了一群魔兽难民。

185935276.review:
The Elder Scrolls Online (ESO) es un MMORPG ambicioso que promete capturar la esencia de la legendaria saga de Bethesda en un formato multijugador masivo. Sin embargo, la experiencia puede ser un arma de doble filo dependiendo de tus expectativas.

Lo positivo:

Un mundo vasto y hermoso: Tamriel está increíblemente detallado, con biomas variados, ciudades icónicas y una atmósfera que remite a los juegos principales.

Contenido inmenso: ESO ofrece años de expansiones, DLCs y actualizaciones que han agregado más zonas, historias y mecánicas. Si eres fan de la narrativa y las misiones secundarias, encontrarás cientos de horas de entretenimiento.

Flexibilidad de clases y combate: El sistema de habilidades es muy personalizable, lo que permite experimentar con diferentes builds y estilos de juego.

Experiencia cooperativa: Aunque puedes jugar solo, las mazmorras, pruebas y PvP brillan más con amigos o una buena guild.

Lo negativo:
Economía desbalanceada: ESO sufre del temido modelo "buy-to-play + microtransacciones". Aunque la suscripción mensual no es obligatoria, sin ella te sentirás limitado en aspectos clave como la capacidad de inventario, la recolección de materiales y el acceso a ciertas zonas. Además, la tienda de coronas está plagada de cosméticos y "conveniencias" que bordean lo abusivo.

Inicio confuso para nuevos jugadores: La curva de aprendizaje puede ser brutal. Si eres nuevo en el género o en la franquicia, las mecánicas y sistemas te abrumarán rápidamente.

Problemas técnicos: A pesar de los años, ESO no está exento de bugs, caídas de servidores y tiempos de carga largos. Esto puede romper la inmersión y frustrar a quienes buscan una experiencia fluida.

Repetición y "grindeo": Aunque las historias principales suelen ser interesantes, muchas actividades secundarias se sienten como un trabajo monótono (cosechar materiales, farmear cofres, etc.).

PvP inconsistente: La experiencia en Cyrodiil (zona de guerra PvP) es irregular, con problemas de lag masivo en las batallas a gran escala.

Veredicto:
The Elder Scrolls Online puede ser una experiencia fantástica si eres fan de la saga, amas los mundos abiertos y tienes paciencia para lidiar con un modelo económico que no siempre es amable. Sin embargo, no es un juego para todos. Si buscas algo más casual o menos dependiente de suscripciones y compras adicionales, tal vez este no sea el MMORPG para ti.

Puntuación: 7/10
Un mundo hermoso con alma, pero atrapado en las garras de su modelo de negocio y algunos problemas técnicos persistentes.

185749110.review:
The Elder Scrolls® Online (ESO) — це не просто гра, це цілий всесвіт, який об’єднує всі світи та локації легендарної франшизи. Від засніженого Скайріму до спекотного Ельсвейру, від загадкових глибин Чорного Ліса до золотих веж Саммерсету — тут кожен куточок Тамріелю оживає перед вашими очима. Для мене, як шанувальника серії, ESO — це унікальна можливість бути частиною цієї епічної історії, а також насолоджуватися пригодами з друзями та однодумцями з усього світу.

Що вражає найбільше, це доступність гри для новачків. Якщо ви раніше не грали в жодну гру серії, не хвилюйтеся: розробники нещодавно випустили оновлення, яке значно полегшує входження в гру для новачків. Тут ви знайдете навчання, простий і зрозумілий вступний контент і можливість одразу зануритися у вибрані пригоди.

Кожне доповнення ESO — це витвір мистецтва. Вони не просто додають нові локації чи механіки, але й відкривають гравцям нові горизонти історій і культур. Наприклад, доповнення «High Isle» занурює у дворянські інтриги, а «Blackwood» відкриває завісу передумов до подій The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion.

Я запрошую всіх, хто коли-небудь мріяв побувати у Тамріелі, спробувати себе в ESO. Незалежно від того, чи ви мрієте стати майстром магії, вправним лучником або ж хоробрим воїном, ця гра знайде для вас місце. Тут є численні гільдії — для любителів PvE, PvP, крафту чи навіть просто для тих, хто любить спілкуватися та досліджувати світ.

The Elder Scrolls® Online — це більше, ніж гра. Це спільнота, де кожен гравець пише власну історію. Приєднуйтесь, ми завжди будемо вас чекати в цьому неймовірному світі.

185681794.review:
This is all really subjective, so the very things I dislike might be things that others like. But I will summarize my issues and as always take with salt. 

1. Game play. I am only level 25 so perhaps it gets more complex. But its the same tired 'I have five skills on a bar' type of game play that was pretty dated with WoW. Its not the model per se; diablo IV uses that approach with a degree of success. Its that the skills don't really work together in any meaningful way. You for example don't seem to take a skill and then create a build around that skill (aka POE and Diablo). I have an attack skill for my sword, a movement skill, a defensive skill. all of which are just sort of meh

2. Build creation. I don't expect POE level complexity, but so far its basically a bunch of pretty bland skills that all seem pretty meh, and dont really evolve that much as you level them. I mean mutating a skill into A or B, with pretty slight differences between the two options, is not exactly robust build creation here. 

3. Leveling experience. Run from quest to question, do something. Watch your leveling bar slowly creep up. Back and forth, back and forth. Again it's not that its 'bad' but seriously its basically cut and paste MMO's from 20 years ago.

4. The basic game engine. You feel like a rag doll, floating across the field, getting stuck on every blade of grass. Nothing has any weight or sense of impact. 

5. The UI. O sweet gods, the UI. It makes me want to claw my eyes out. 

Now all of these complaints are a bit unfair. To me this feels like an old, dated MMO that has simply not kept up with the times.  It is also the simplest game I think I have ever played. 

So those are my complaints, but I hesitate to call it 'bad'. Clearly there are positives: The game works, there are tons of people in the game itself, and it has been around for years. So clearly there are things that lots of folks do like. 

Perhaps just unfortunate that I could not see those positives during my (limited) time.

185631361.review:
Elder Scrolls Online (ESO) is the epitome of squandered potential, riddled with problems that would make even the staunchest fans reconsider their loyalty.

The game is plagued with years-old bugs that Zenimax has either ignored or half-heartedly addressed. The lag and atrocious server performance are inexcusable for a game this size. Every time there’s an issue, they trot out the same tired excuse: “It’s a DDOS attack.” At this point, that explanation feels more like a running joke. Face it, Zenimax—it’s your subpar servers.

The overland difficulty is practically non-existent. It’s a theme park for players who want to stroll through quests without any challenge. There’s no satisfaction in defeating enemies when they’re little more than cardboard cutouts.

This game isn’t an MMO; it’s a cash grab simulator. Regular content updates? Forget about it. The only thing Zenimax reliably churns out is new items for the cash shop. And let’s talk about those loot boxes—a sleazy, exploitative tactic designed to milk money from players. There’s no significant in-game progression or meaningful rewards; everything funnels you toward spending more in the store.

The game’s gear system is laughable. 90% of the gear is utterly useless, a staggering testament to poor design. It’s as if the developers threw stats into a spreadsheet without considering whether they would actually work in practice. Balance changes are equally nonsensical, made with seemingly no regard for the actual gameplay experience.

ESO is an exercise in frustration, a game that prioritizes monetization over player experience. With its bugs, bad servers, non-existent challenge, and exploitative business practices, it’s hard to recommend this game to anyone who values their time or money. Avoid it unless you enjoy being nickel-and-dimed while fighting lag.

185468102.review:
This game is a complicated one to recommend. Played heavily on console before switching to PC. Overall, I think this game is great, but your enjoyment will depend heavily on what you are looking for. If you love Elder Scrolls lore and quests, then this is a game for you. I primarily play solo, but there is plenty of dungeons, group content, and trials (this game's version of raids) to do. Some quest lines are better than others, but some of my favorite stories have been found in this game. There's also multiple types of PVP, but I have limited experience with that since I tend to not do PVP in MMOs.

I think this game has some of the best character customization of all the major mmos right now, but it can be a bit complex. Classes are more of a thematic choice than anything else with every class being able to fill any of the three roles. Then there are more skill lines you can unlock as you play through quest lines. Every class can use every weapon with each weapon type having it's own skill line. Then when you hit level 50, you unlock the Champion system which allows you to fine tune your character. Of course you can look up builds, but I find it more fun to experiment, respecing frequently, and finding different combos that work. However, depending on your build, you can quickly become overpowered with a lot of content. There is harder content in this game, but most of the quests will be a breeze. This does get a little disappointing when you spend hours enjoying a questline that has been building up a major enemy. Only for them to take 30 seconds to fight because of how easy they are to beat. 

Something to keep in mind if you are interested in playing is how the monetization works. You can buy the starter edition which gives you the base game and the Morrowind chapter. This hundreds of hours of content, but there's also going to be a lot of other content that comes with the later DLCs and there's a lot of them. You can pay for the monthly subscription and get access to everything and earn the premium currency every month. This is the more standard MMO experience like WOW or FFXIV where you have to pay monthly no matter what. This will not give you the most recent chapter though. Of course you can also just buy the expansions that you want to play, a la carte style. The biggest issue I have with this is that the craft bag is locked behind the sub. This makes non-sub players really struggle with inventory management as the game has become bloated with crafting materials. This is great if you really like crafting and pay for the sub, but will quickly become frustrating with inventory management if you don't pay.

The future of the game is also at an interesting point. I'm choosing to remain optimistic with it, but we will see with time. They've announced that Gold Road will be the last chapter and they are changing their content model to seasons instead. Many people have labeled this as the game going into "maintenence mode". I don't think that is the case as Bethesda has another game that uses the season model instead of expansions: Fallout 76. Love that game or hate it, it has gotten a lot of good content over the years with this model. But that is to be seen with what it will look like with ESO. 

My only other biggest issue is just how often I have trouble logging in. I constantly get the error that there is an unexpected internal error and it won't let me log in. Nothing will ever fix this issue. I just have to wait for a bit and try again and usually I'm able to log in. Not the end of the world, but it is an annoying regular issue.

185201748.review:
*I have a lot more playtime on the official launcher than I do on steam, for whatever that matters.*

The game is fun, it has alot going for it. It's probably the most immersive MMORPG I've played. The combat
feels better than it looks, though its very frustrating that your class choice feels useless since most of your
build will end up coming from skill lines available to all classes, and ever since Arcanists release, all the other
classes feel dead compared to it. Dragon Knight is second place in terms of still being worth playing, but by and large, the rest of the classes, especially necromancer, just suck to play. For the record, I'm talking about my experience in PvE, as I don't do ESO PvP. 

The weapon skill animations especially feel lackluster, bow is the worst offender with its light and heavy attack animation. Scribing allows us to- in a VERY limited capacity that effectively amounts to yet another cash grab- change the color of SOME skills. But its a far cry from the animation overhaul that was needed.

Some of the more recent systems are cool ideas, like scribing, that have been implemented quite poorly. Instead of changing up your skills like it sounded like at first, it just gives you a new skill in each category 
that you can tweak after you unlock it. Players are getting really tired of the microtransactions, its especially bad for new players that don't know what to expect from zos. There is a lot of bloat in the crown store that is really just there to scam unsuspecting players, things that are not, and will never be worth your Crowns ($) and Gems (gambling scraps). There remain many design choices that are just stupid and hinder players. You charge crowns to gift something to a friend, only to find out that your account- which has been in good standing since BETA in 2014- is not eligible to gift crownstore items. Apparently you have to file a support ticket just to ask to gift things with your already spent money. So many things in this game are so much more of a hassle than they need to be. If the developers have any common sense, it is overruled by the
finance team and reduced to r**ard level choices by the time it reaches the players.

The gambling is especially bad. The things you are spending 80$+ to try and get are so rare that you will never get them unless you sink multiple hundreds trying. Admittedly you can farm Seals and get things
that way, but its very, very, very slow. You need 16,000 seals for a radiant mount, and you can farm only 30 per day with a bonus of 250 per week. On top of this, you only have three months before the stock changes,
Personally, every time I have gambled- I am left with nothing but immense regret and cosmetics that aren't what I wanted and will never use. 

The community is fairly good. Most people are willing to help a newbie out, crafters will be happy to craft for you if ask politely. Guilds are constantly recruiting and the playerbase is active. It can be a bit tough to learn some of the dungeons as veteran players speedrun them so aggressively that you wont be able to keep up or have time to learn mechanics unless you look up a guide, which isn't a big deal given that most of this is decade old content, but it is a hurdle for newer players.

If you have a problem with DEI content, ESO has it. There isn't alot, but you see bits of it here and there. Especially with some of the npc companion quests. (unlockable AI party members)

At the end of the day, the game is still very good, but it is weighed down by cash grab design choices and a lack of QoL you would expect in a ten year old game. Many games have a lot of potential but fail to truly reach anything close to what they can be. This is true of ESO even more than usual. The game world is truly massive, and beautiful, but the game systems and available activities outside of combat truly fail to capitalize on the world they have crafted.

I don't regret my time spent on ESO. I don't regret buying it. I do regret every penny I've spent on micro-transactions, because the gambling and baiting is just that bad. 

I wouldn't recommend anyone new to MMORPGs to try it, it would be gruesomely frustrating for them. And for anyone who is an MMO veteran, proceed with caution. The game is good, but it is not even in the same reality as the concept of "user friendly".

Last word? If you love Elder scrolls type gameplay, you will find ESO to be an amusing attempt to spin it into an MMORPG. It falls far short of the singleplayer games, but it can still be a good time in the same world with the same or similar concepts. And you get to share it with other players. Sometimes that means fighting them for chest spawns, sometimes that means partnering up with strangers to raid public dungeons. My final bit of advice? If you have never played ESO and want to start, find a friend who knows the game to help you. Navigating this particular MMORPG is as dangerous as any dungeon, with far more traps set by the developers to waste your time and steal your money. Most of them can be avoided if you are aware of them.

Good luck.

185181157.review:
The Elder Scrolls Online – Ein Spiel mit viel Potenzial, das leider nicht mein Herz erobern konnte

Die Welt von Tamriel, aber auf eine andere Art.

The Elder Scrolls Online (ESO) ist ein Spiel, das mit unbestreitbarem Potenzial aufwartet. Als jemand, der die Welt von Skyrim liebt und in vielen Einzelspielertiteln tief eingetaucht ist, war die Vorstellung, diese Erlebnisse online mit Freunden zu teilen, zunächst ein verlockender Gedanke. ESO bietet eine riesige, lebendige Welt, in der du zusammen mit anderen Abenteurern die Geheimnisse von Tamriel aufdecken kannst – eine faszinierende Aussicht, die in der Theorie alles hatte, was ich mir wünschte. Doch leider bin ich mit dem Spiel einfach nicht richtig warm geworden.
Das Spielprinzip – Viele Möglichkeiten, aber irgendwie nicht ganz meins

ESO bietet eine beeindruckende Freiheit, die dir erlaubt, deinen eigenen Spielstil zu kreieren. Ob du kämpfen, Handwerk betreiben, stehlen oder die Welt auf eigene Faust erkunden möchtest – hier kannst du dich ganz nach deinen Wünschen entfalten. Das klingt großartig, und viele Spieler schätzen genau diese Vielseitigkeit. Doch trotz der vielen Optionen fühlte sich das Gameplay oft leer und repetitiv an. In der weiten Welt von Tamriel gibt es unzählige Quests, aber es war nicht immer die Art von Abenteuer, die mich packte. Vielleicht liegt es an meiner Vorliebe für die Einzelspielererfahrungen der Elder Scrolls-Reihe, aber Online-RPGs haben einfach nicht denselben Charme für mich.
Erzähle deine eigene Geschichte – Aber irgendwie mit weniger Magie

Die Möglichkeit, deine eigene Geschichte zu erleben, ist ein zentraler Bestandteil von ESO. Die Erzählweise und die Struktur des Spiels bieten dir eine tiefe und komplexe Geschichte, die in vielen Aspekten faszinierend ist. Doch irgendwie fehlte mir die Magie, die Skyrim oder Oblivion für mich so besonders gemacht haben. Es war nicht nur die Epik der Erzählung, die fehlte – es war auch das Gefühl von Isolation und Entdeckung. In ESO läuft alles in großen, oft überfüllten Online-Welten ab, und das Gefühl, ein echter Held in einer lebendigen Welt zu sein, wurde leider ein wenig durch die ständige Präsenz anderer Spieler getrübt.
Die technischen Aspekte – Frustrationen, die die Freude trüben

Ein weiterer Punkt, der mir schwer auf den Schultern lag, waren die konstanten Updates und die enorme Dateigröße des Spiels. Mit über 130 GB zu Beginn und zusätzlichen 100 GB für Updates, ist es kaum zu fassen, wie viel Speicherplatz dieses Spiel einnimmt. Wenn man bedenkt, dass gerade in einer Zeit, in der die Festplattenkapazitäten begrenzt sind, solch ein Massivspiel vor einem liegt, ist das eine ziemliche Hürde. Klar, Updates gehören dazu, aber es ist frustrierend, wenn das Spiel scheinbar nie „fertig“ ist und immer wieder eine noch größere Menge an Speicherplatz verlangt.
Die Kontroversen – Politik und DLCs, die den Spaß mindern

Die politische Ausrichtung und die Entscheidungen der Entwickler, die neue, ideologische Themen in das Spiel zu integrieren, haben bei mir ebenfalls für Unbehagen gesorgt. Die Absicht, bestimmte Themen in einem Spiel anzusprechen, mag vielleicht gut gemeint sein, aber ich habe das Gefühl, dass solche Elemente die Stimmung trüben und vom ursprünglichen Spaß des Spiels ablenken. Als Spieler will man einfach in eine neue Welt eintauchen und sich nicht mit Themen konfrontiert sehen, die mehr politisch als spielerisch motiviert erscheinen.

Zudem haben die ständigen DLCs und Mikrotransaktionen ihren Tribut gefordert. Als jemand, der mit den klassischen „alles-in-einem-Paket“-Spielen groß geworden ist, war es schwer, mich an das moderne Modell von Online-Spielen zu gewöhnen, bei dem man für zusätzliche Inhalte ständig extra bezahlen muss. Für mich nahm das irgendwie etwas von der Freude und dem Komfort, das Spiel in seiner vollen Pracht zu erleben, ohne immer an weitere Käufe und Erweiterungen denken zu müssen.
Fazit – Ein solides Spiel, aber nicht mein Fall

The Elder Scrolls Online hat zweifellos eine große und treue Community, und für viele bietet es eine fantastische Möglichkeit, die Welt von Tamriel in einer neuen Art und Weise zu erleben. Die Freiheit in der Charaktergestaltung, die umfangreiche Welt und die Möglichkeit, das Spiel mit anderen zu teilen, sind die Stärken, die ESO zu einem beliebten Titel machen. Doch für mich persönlich war es einfach nicht das gleiche Gefühl wie bei den klassischen Elder Scrolls-Spielen. Das Spiel bietet viele beeindruckende Features, aber ich kann nicht leugnen, dass ich eher der Einzelspieler-Typ bin, der sich in die tiefen, offenen Welten von Skyrim und Oblivion stürzt.

Fazit: Wenn du ein großer Fan von Skyrim bist und dir schon immer gewünscht hast, diese Erfahrung im Mehrspieler-Modus zu erleben, könnte The Elder Scrolls Online genau das Richtige für dich sein. Wenn du jedoch, wie ich, die isolierte und erzählerische Tiefe eines Einzelspielerspiels bevorzugst, wirst du dich hier möglicherweise nicht ganz zu Hause fühlen. Trotz allem bleibt es ein gut gemachtes und beeindruckendes Online-RPG, das seinen Platz im Genre verdient.

185024858.review:
Ignore the "4 hrs played": I've been playing this game since beta, just usually not through Steam. I'm trying it just to see if it'll fix an issue I'm having with detecting it in the Nvidia App, since there's currently a reward for running it for 50 mins through Nvidia.

No Steam Achievements, I consider a plus, as the plethora of ingame achievements can be grindier than I prefer for Steam.

No reall "pay-to-win": their ingame purchases are almost all about cosmetics, though there's also a fair bit of "pay-for-convenience". Like, buying the monthly "ESO+" subscription gives you much more storage space, etc, to the point that most longtime players swear by it as it just makes the game way more convenient. Similarly, you can buy pets who act as shopkeepers, bankers, etc. so you don't have to lug your loot back to a town. If you've already achieved something grindy on one character, you can usually pay to unlock it on another character to avoid doing the grind again; I've never bothered, but nice that the option's there. Most cool stuff (mounts, housing, etc) can be obtained for free; you can just get more of them with money.

Different areas of the game have different modes: single-player, or play casually with friends ("overland PvE" - what I'll talk about most here), group co-op ("Group PvE": Trials, Group Dungeons), and player-vs-player ("PvP").

Like myself, I'd say most players come from the single-player Elder Scrolls fanbase, rather than from other MMO fanbases, so we want single-player or casual small-group co-op content. Most agree that PvP just isn't the game's main strength. PvP has three forms: open-world battles based around besieging keeps across Cyrodiil (I rarely see more than a couple dozen people in a siege, though); similar fighting but in the Imperial city, where it's more about capture-the-flag; and 4v4 "battlegrounds". It's OK if that's what you're into.

Some areas require or at least encourage co-op. At the moment, even the areas which encourage co-op ("Group Dungeons") can mostly be solo'd unless you go for the harder "veteran" difficulty, though a few dungeons have "mechanics" that require two or more people. Trials are 12-person things where you go up against heftier NPC opponents ("mobs"). Trials and Dungeons are non-casual, in that it's kinda a jerk move to drop out in the middle of running one.

The overwhelming majority of the world, however, is "overland". Despite its name, this includes a lot of the underground smaller delves. You can do this in a group or alone, but really, solo play is *better* unless you commit to doing quests together, otherwise you fall out of synch, where one person has a quest to run off and complete, while someone else has already done it. Like, my wife and I have characters reserved just for playing together. Fro the most part they've made it so that you at least CAN group together, though, regardless of whether you've done the quest in that area or not.

But casual PvE is where the game shines.

It's clearly what all the devs enjoy, and clearly what most players do, too. There is *months* of story-based quest content, that mostly isn't just oldschool-MMO "kill 10 rats and come back" but more like "find out who's behind nefarious goings-on by searching for clues, talking to people, fighting, exploring, interacting with the world, etc". Not saying there aren't any grindy quests: just that they aren't the norm.

The main questline of the area is story-based, and there're a significant number of story-based side-quests in each zone too. Just about every delve has one, plus there are many others throughout the world, as both fixed and random encounters.

Then each zone has about three repeatable "daily" quests (meaning you can't usually pick up the quest more than once a day, not that you have to do 'em all every day: there's well over a hundred!). These are usually one simple "kill <random boss>", one "do some repeating world event", and one "complete a delve", but can also include things like "win a card game" or "sneak through this area and assassinate a target" or "steal an item in this building" or... you get the idea.

As well as the solo questing, there's also lots of other things to do: the "tales of Tribute" card game I already mentioned; legerdemain has you picking pockets and stealing from houses; crafting is a whole specialty you can sink years into mastering; fishing (collect 9 rare fish from each zone for an achievement); housing (you can buy and craft furniture, invite people to it, and make things convenient by putting all sorts of utilities like bankers, merchants, crafting tables, training dummies, mundus stones, etc all close together; you can tour other people's works and see some truly amazing stuff they've made (my favorite was a Borg Cube); arenas (where you go through several rounds of monsters, in interesting environments that make it harder but more interesting); the "infinite archive" (like an arena, but an unlimited number of rounds); antiquities (where you solve a couple of simple puzzle minigames to find and dig up interesting things); and more I'm forgetting.

The game is designed to support being played intermittently; you pick it up when there's an event, or a new release, and then you drop it for a while, and come back when there's something else cool going on. But at the same time, it's also designed to make you WANT to keep playing, to complete that outfit, to finish decorating that house, etc.

Overall: I've been playing for over ten years, and there's still so much I haven't yet done in the game. And I likely never will, because they expand it at least as fast as I can consume the content.

Достоинства: Переведена на русский язык, атмосфера, стоимость, механика.
Недостатки: Нет
Кто давным давно играл в трилогию свитков - The Elder Scrolls, особенно фанатом серий запомнились дополнения Morrovind и Oblivion, знают, что 6 лет назад разработчики сделали онлайн версию, для всех игроков, фанатов, которые как раз таки и могут играть вместе. Но в начале не было всё так гладко и вот почему...
Для русских игроков конечно же важен перевод, а так как эта игра иностранного производства, изначально не была локализирована для русского слоя населения. Имела множество недочетов, багов, ко всему прочему её стоимость непоперно завышенной. А так же обязательная платная подписка, дабы можно было в неё играть. Что же сейчас в 2025 году?

Безусловно за 11 лет игра полностью изменилась и буквально ожила вновь. Лично я застал две эпохи: НАЧАЛО и НАСТОЯЩЕЕ время. Теперь играть можно, так как игра полностью переведена на русский язык, обязательная подписка убрана, а стоимость игры снизилась в 5 раз - (частенько делают скидки и можете урвать по сказочной цене в 379 рублей, в отличии от стандартной в данное время 879). Радует это? Безусловно! Помимо всего прочего, были сделаны множество доработок механики игры. Её работа стала более плавной и оптимизированной.

Если вы фанат TES, то просто обязаны окунуться в мир свитков ОНЛАЙН и повидать всё своими глазами, ведь получите от этого самые настоящие удовольствия от проведенного с ней времени.

184858123.review:
Рекомендую эту игру для тех, кто любит проходить квестики в формате визуальной новеллы, а также для домостроителей и РПшеров. Квестов тут очень МНОГО, и разные временные линии наслаиваются друг на друга, поэтому без гайда по прохождению квестов вам не обойтись.

Не рекомендую эту игру для тех, кто привык нажимать по 10 кнопок за 1 секунду. Хоть в игре и есть вивинг (вставление легких атак оружием между прожатием скиллов), но вместе с тем тут очень МНОГО багов, из-за которых у вас будет взрываться жопа в самом сложном контенте. 

Начну с огромного МИНУСА. Разработчики, судя по всему, толком и не играют в свою же игру. Поэтому в игре есть баги, которые не исправляются годами и не исправятся никогда. Например, в подземельях есть мобы, застревающие в текстурах, или те же мобы могут застывать на месте и продолжать агриться на вас даже тогда, когда вы уже прошли почти все подземелье. Про баги с не работающим блоком и доджем (кувырком) я вообще молчу. И так продолжать можно бесконечно.

В игре есть испытания. Это такое огромное подземелье на 12 человек. В этих испытаниях со слабым компьютером у вас будет все лагать и фризить, а без специального аддона вы не сможете увидеть своего персонажа в куче светящихся боевых эффектов. Но это только в испытаниях, в остальном контенте все нормально.

Теперь ПЛЮСЫ. Есть и положительные моменты, например, почти каждый год выходит новая глава. Кстати, при выходе небольшого дополнения с островом Гален сломался блок, он просто переставал нажиматься в рандомный момент. Разработчики вообще полгода не могли починить это и, в итоге, просто откатили все обновления назад.

Среди прочего в игре очень хорошая звуковая составляющая. Музыка на высоте.

В общем, если вы готовы впустую потеть в погоне за динамичными боями и покорением самых высоких вершин PvE и PvP контента, то можете смело покупать эту игру.

I do not recommend anyone purchase or play The Elder Scrolls Online or any of the DLC.  It is an old MMORPG that despite whatever Zenimax Online Studios would like you to believe is about to enter maintenance mode and will exist only to milk current players (driven to play by their addiction or the sunk cost fallacy) for their money.

I never liked light attack weaving and animation cancelling (to provide sufficient damage per second for high-end PvE content).
I never liked having many different auction houses, trading posts, or trading companies that are paid for and run by guilds (as opposed to a centralized auction house that is populated by individual players).
I never liked the monthly subscription fee, ESO store currencies, or loot boxes.  The prices for individual purchases were equally as insane.
I didn't like the performance issues experienced while playing the game (i.e. the occasional "why am I getting extremely low frames per second?",  "why is my ping or latency in milliseconds out of control?", or "why did I just get disconnected from the server?").

In light of recent updates, events, and controversies concerning Zenimax Online Studios I figured I'd come back and leave a review just to say that overall The Elder Scrolls Online was good for a time, but that time has long been over with.

Elder Scrolls Online Reviewed by someone who doesn't generally like MMOs.

Pros:
-Quest at your own freedom in almost any area
-Strong Elder Scrolls vibes.
-Enjoyable and fun abilities.
-Fun quests with engaging stories.

Cons:
-Traversal can be frustrating due to obstacles like rocks and steep hills forcing you to take pointless detours.
-Ability pathing can be confusing; an undo option for morphed abilities would be helpful.
-Can definitely feel overwhelming at times.

The format of this MMO is both entertaining and liberating, offering numerous quality-of-life features. The early game is enjoyable, and the end game remains engaging. Overall, I’d rate it an 9/10 for MMOs (Keep in mind I don't usually like MMOs) and a 7/10 overall. It’s especially fun with friends, and the game boasts an active and engaging community.

I’d recommend getting the game on sale, though the full price isn’t a bad deal if you’re impatient.

184653339.review:
The game itself has many positive aspects for casual players. However, if you're into veteran dungeons/raids, you'll find out that the Devs (Zenimax) are EXTREMELY incompetent and unprofessional. They don't actually dedicate time to fixing bugs. They say they will, but then we have bugs that have been around for over FIVE YEARS. On top of that, they don't play their own game and from the very little they have shown on streams, they don't even have people within the company who are able to play and properly test veteran raiding.
Forums? Good luck with that. Any criticism is viewed as an attack, and answered either with a ban or with generic statements that don't actually mean anything.

Here's a few examples of bugs: 
- You and a friend queue for a dungeon together as dps and tank. If the dps queues, you get in almost immediately. If the tank queues, the queue can bug and you'll get an endless wait, unless you keep regrouping and relogging. But then, when you try to regroup, you get sometimes a message that you are already in a group, even if you aren't.
- join a raid group, port into the trial and the game kicks you from group immediately. In a loop. Doesn't matter how many times you try again.
- You are in the middle of a raid and the servers disconnect you (which btw happens often). If you try to log back in immediately, which is normal to try to do, you get A LOGIN ERROR AND CANT LOG IN FOR FIVE MINUTES.
- They don't have enough servers and they are poorly maintained, so each time an Event happens, raid instances are laggy and people get disconnected often. To make matters worse, they recently changed the game so when someone disconnects in raid, you lose vitality. So, if your raid is trying to get an achievement without deaths and someone disconnects, even if they dc alive, you'll lose vitality and will have to restart a 20 minute run.
- There are serious heal/buff bugs, where certain skills don't target the players who need it. Like the same buff will refresh on the same players when you recast, instead of targeting first the players who dont have the buff yet. Some heals target people who are full health instead of low health.

The list goes on and on and these problems have been around for LITERAL YEARS and they either don't care, or don't have people competent enough to fix issues. It's sad. The game has an amazing combat system and is fun with friends, but Zenimax seems committed to getting all players to quit the game.

The in-game store is always full and updated with reskins of the same items, though. For that, they seem to have time.

184530352.review:
[h1]🛡️ The Elder Scrolls Online : Tamriel, le terrain de jeu de vos rêves (ou cauchemars) 🛡️[/h1]  
[p]Temps de jeu : Une vie entière (ou jusqu’à ce que vous réalisiez que vous avez passé 100 heures à chercher Azura dans un pot de fleurs).[/p]  
[p]Genre : MMORPG dans l’univers riche et complexe des Elder Scrolls.[/p]  
[hr]  
[p]**The Elder Scrolls Online (TESO)** vous plonge dans l’univers mythique de Tamriel, où vous pouvez croiser les échos de figures légendaires comme Vivec, Sheogorath, ou même le bon vieux Pelinal Whitestrake (ne mentionnez pas les elfes devant lui, on vous aura prévenu). Que vous soyez un vétéran de Skyrim qui hurle encore "Fus Ro Dah" à son chien ou un nouveau venu fasciné par l’idée de devenir la main droite d’un Daedra, TESO est prêt à vous accueillir. Mais attention : Tamriel n’attend pas les retardataires, surtout si vous croisez Molag Bal en pleine mauvaise humeur.[/p]  

[h2]Gameplay et contenu :[/h2]  
[p]🌍 **Un monde aussi vaste qu’un livre d’Urag gro-Shub** : Tamriel regorge de régions variées, des îles idylliques de Summerset aux marécages crasseux de Black Marsh. Si vous êtes du genre à vous perdre dans un livre, attendez de voir ce que ça donne dans un monde vivant où chaque recoin raconte une histoire. Même Sheogorath aurait du mal à suivre tout ce qui s’y passe.[/p]  
[p]⚔️ **Des combats où vous êtes l’héroïne ou le héros de votre propre poème épique** : Le système de combat actif vous permet de bloquer, esquiver, et attaquer, comme si vous étiez le Dragonborn lui-même. Mais rappelez-vous : peu importe votre talent, vous ne serez jamais aussi cool que Divayth Fyr lançant un sort d’une seule main.[/p]  
[p]🎭 **Créez votre propre légende (et évitez de devenir une blague dans le lore)** : Que vous soyez un mage pyromane ou un archer qui ne touche jamais sa cible (bonjour, Cicéron !), TESO offre une liberté totale pour façonner votre histoire. Allez-y, faites-vous un personnage à la hauteur de Nerevar… ou pas.[/p]  
[p]🏰 **Un contenu varié digne des Neuf Divins** : Du PvP épique à Cyrodiil où vous pouvez imaginer devenir le nouvel empereur, jusqu’aux donjons à plusieurs où l’un d’entre vous oubliera inévitablement de bloquer. Et pour les fans de Vivec, il y a toujours un coin pour méditer… ou tomber d’un toit.[/p]  
[p]📖 **Des quêtes écrites avec amour… et parfois un peu de folie** : Certaines quêtes vous plongeront dans des récits épiques dignes de Talos, tandis que d’autres vous demanderont de ramasser des trucs pour un PNJ qui aurait très bien pu le faire lui-même. Ah, les traditions Elder Scrolls.[/p]  
[p]🤝 **Une communauté où même un Bosmer peut se faire des amis** : Tamriel est rempli de joueurs prêts à vous aider, que ce soit pour combattre un boss de zone ou pour organiser des soirées RP où tout le monde prétend être un serviteur de Nocturne.[/p]  

[h2]Les points positifs :[/h2]  
[p]🌟 **Exploration sans limite** : Grâce à la synchronisation des niveaux, vous pouvez aller où vous voulez. Oui, même dans une grotte où Barbas vous jugera en silence parce que vous êtes venu sans préparation.[/p]  
[p]🎨 **Une direction artistique digne d’un livre sacré de Julianos** : Le jeu est toujours aussi beau, et chaque mise à jour apporte son lot d’améliorations. Parfait pour vos screenshots héroïques… ou vos selfies avec Sheogorath.[/p]  
[p]🎵 **Une bande-son qui ferait pleurer même Jauffre** : Les musiques orchestrales vous feront sentir comme le héros de Kvatch à chaque instant, même si vous ramassez des champignons pour un alchimiste.[/p]  
[p]📅 **Des mises à jour régulières, bénies par Arkay** : Entre les chapitres annuels et les nouvelles zones, le contenu ne cesse de s’étoffer, pour que vous ne manquiez jamais de choses à faire.[/p]  

[h2]Les points négatifs :[/h2]  
[p]💰 **Un modèle économique à la Clavicus Vile** : Vous pouvez tout obtenir sans payer… si vous êtes prêt à attendre éternellement ou à négocier votre patience contre ESO Plus et des couronnes. Peut-être qu’Hermaeus Mora aurait un meilleur deal pour vous.[/p]  
[p]⏳ **Un apprentissage aussi profond que l’Oubli** : Si vous débutez, le jeu peut sembler écrasant, comme si vous étiez un apprenti face à la bibliothèque d’Urag gro-Shub. Mais persévérez, et vous serez bientôt aussi sage qu’un Moth Priest.[/p]  
[p]🏃‍♂️ **Déplacements un peu longs, même pour un Argonien** : Même avec les téléportations, certaines zones vous forceront à marcher comme un pèlerin perdu. Heureusement, il y a toujours quelque chose d’intéressant sur le chemin… comme un loup qui veut votre peau.[/p]  

[hr]  
[p]En résumé, **The Elder Scrolls Online** est un MMO où les fans de l’univers de Tamriel trouveront de quoi s’immerger pleinement. Que vous vouliez marcher sur les traces de héros légendaires comme Tiber Septim ou simplement devenir le Dovahkiin de la pêche à la ligne, TESO vous offre un monde riche, vivant et rempli de surprises. Alors, préparez votre Daedric cuirassé, rassemblez votre courage, et entrez dans l’histoire de Tamriel. N’oubliez pas : dans TESO, même une quête anodine peut vous mener à une rencontre avec un Prince Daedra… Ou a un garde qui a pris une flèche dans le genou.[/p]

184481449.review:
I would recommend this game to people who want a game to waste time on. This game a whole bunch of systems that take a very long time to max out. For example, the Scrying and Excavating tree that you get from the antiquity quest-line takes ages to upgrade just to unlock the ability to scry high tier gear. Also, this is only available for that one character you did it on, and not account wide. Which is BS. To become a crafter takes a long time too, you have to level up your tree by doing daily writs (for ages), and getting the traits off of other gear for your collection, which has a cooldown. Basically if you aren't invested for the long haul you'll have to ask other people to craft you items and even miss out on high-tier loot, just because they have these horrible systems. Everything else is fun. The story is great, the amount of quality quests is good, and the ability to utilize mods is great! One thing I would recommend though, is to get the subscription just because it makes your life a lot easier and cheaper, since the DLCs are expensive to buy just themselves. Also, you get a crafting bag which makes the game playable for the most part; why I say this, is due to the fact that you have no bank or inventory space. You'll have to create mules just to hold your loot and materials if you don't have the subscription. An added bonus is recieving 1650 crowns to spend in the crown store.

Side-note: don't spend your crowns on the crates thinking you'll get something good, because you won't. The chances of getting a good item is slim. You'll just get consumables which are worse than the things you can craft and some subpar cosmetic that doesn't look that good. If you really want an item in their though, there's a chance of getting it. Expect to spend a lot of money to receive that item though.

184378228.review:
The Elder Scrolls Online: Un Universo Vivo que Nunca Deja de Sorprender
Si alguna vez soñaste con perderte en un mundo rico en historias, aventuras y una belleza inmersiva que desafía los límites del tiempo, The Elder Scrolls Online (ESO) es la puerta de entrada a esa utopía. Bethesda y ZeniMax han logrado crear no solo un videojuego, sino una experiencia que redefine lo que significa estar dentro de un universo vivo.

1. Un Mundo que Respira Magia e Historia
Tamriel nunca ha sido tan vibrante como lo es en ESO. Desde las dunas abrasadoras de Elsweyr hasta los majestuosos picos nevados de Skyrim, cada región es un cuadro viviente que late con la promesa de aventuras únicas. Cada rincón tiene un secreto que contar, cada cueva una leyenda que explorar, y cada personaje una historia que escuchar. La diversidad de biomas y culturas es tan vasta que da la sensación de que Tamriel nunca dejará de sorprenderte.

2. Una Historia Personalizada para Ti
La narrativa de ESO no solo respeta el lore clásico de la franquicia Elder Scrolls; lo eleva. Cada misión está escrita con un nivel de detalle impresionante, ofreciendo giros inesperados y momentos emotivos. A diferencia de otros MMORPG, aquí eres más que un jugador; eres el héroe de una epopeya que evoluciona según tus decisiones.

3. Una Comunidad Vibrante y Acogedora
Desde el momento en que pones un pie en Tamriel, la comunidad de ESO te recibe con los brazos abiertos. Tanto si eres un jugador experimentado como un principiante, encontrarás gremios dispuestos a ayudarte, eventos comunitarios que unen a jugadores de todo el mundo y una atmósfera colaborativa que rara vez se encuentra en otros títulos multijugador.

4. Jugabilidad que Abarca Todo Tipo de Estilo
¿Eres un guerrero incansable que busca el combate más desafiante? ¿O quizás un artesano que disfruta creando las armas y armaduras más codiciadas? ESO ofrece algo para todos. Con un sistema de combate dinámico y una personalización de habilidades que permite combinar clases, armas y magia, la creatividad es la clave para destacar en el campo de batalla.

5. Una Cascada Constante de Actualizaciones
ZeniMax nunca deja de sorprendernos con contenido fresco. Cada expansión y DLC es una obra de arte que añade nuevas áreas, historias y mecánicas de juego. Además, los eventos de temporada y festivales aseguran que siempre haya algo emocionante en el horizonte.

6. Gráficos y Música que Tocan el Alma
La estética de ESO es simplemente impresionante. Cada paisaje está diseñado con esmero, mientras que la música, con sus composiciones orquestales épicas, no solo acompaña al jugador, sino que lo transporta emocionalmente. El tema principal, en particular, es un himno que captura la esencia misma de la aventura.

¿Por Qué No Puedo Dejar de Jugar ESO?
Porque ESO no es solo un juego; es un viaje. Es la posibilidad de convertirte en el héroe de tu propia historia, de unir fuerzas con jugadores de todo el mundo y de ser testigo de cómo un universo sigue creciendo y evolucionando con el tiempo.

Si estás buscando una experiencia que trascienda el género MMORPG y ofrezca un nivel de inmersión que pocos juegos logran alcanzar, The Elder Scrolls Online es una elección obligatoria.

Calificación final: 10/10.
Tamriel te espera, y créeme, no te arrepentirás de responder a su llamado.

184311111.review:
The servers have had lag issues and login session issues for over 3 years now. It's extremely common to have 999 ping in this game when your internet is otherwise great, and when this high ping situation happens, it's usually accompanied with getting forcefully logged out and being unable to log back in until they have whatever server issues under control that are causing the lost connections. It can get extremely bad to the point where it truly is unplayable, and that really really stings if you're paying 20+ bucks a month for an "ESO Plus" subscription.

The balancing in each update is almost always terrible. What ends up generally happening is the staff cater so much to balancing for the PvP element of the game to appease the 25% of players that do PvP, but these changes throw the 75% who play PvE, under the bus. A class like Warden, which is generally mediocre or on the weak side in PvE, will get nerfed further because of 1 tiny weird strat that gives it a slight advantage in a niche PvP case. Another issue about balancing that I can't particularly prove, but I know is the case just from experience, is that they purposely make their newest paid content greatly OP to entice more sales, and then nerf that new content once it's free with ESO+. So it ends up as a situation where "balancing" isn't really about "balancing" but more about making sure the newest content is juicy enough to pay extra for. I can't particularly prove this, but check my hours and please take my word for it.

Another bad thing about this game is that it's very poorly moderated. When a user makes a report about another user, or the not-so-accurate cheat detection system thinks you're speedhacking because you're wearing the fastest gear in the game (true story), you will be guilty until proven innocent. Their policy for handling accusations is to ban the accused for 72 hours immediately without any form of proof. The accused then has to jump through hoops to appeal the ban, which results in a back-and-forth with an automated response system approximately 4-5 times until it is finally sent to a human for review. By that time, your ban is over, but you still have to jump through the hoops so that you don't keep the erroneous strike on your account, since you will be perma banned after 3-4 strikes. 

The game itself is not bad at all when the servers aren't choking to death, but the extra nonsense that comes with it is definitely not worth it, especially for an MMO. It really sucks when you've invested SO much time into a game and the game ends up going downhill so bad managerially that you end up feeling like you lost a good chunk of your life to something that all of a sudden after many good years, suddenly crashed and burned.

They also manage their forums in a very sketchy way, shutting down almost all threads that criticize things in the game, and overall extremely aggressive forum moderation to the point where there's not much you're allowed to say about the game other than good things. They have a "if you don't have anything nice to say don't say anything at all" kind of policy on their forums, which can be good, unless you think that any form of critique is not nice and answer back with a banhammer.

Last thing to note, the scam/scambot scene is rampant in the game. Every 5 minutes your zone chat will have a new message from someone trying to "sell" in game stuff using stolen credit cards. You then get banned if you fall for their scam because your account is then tied to a purchase from a verified stolen CC. Most people with sense can smell these scams from a mile away, but it doesn't take away the fact that every 5 damn minutes you'll be reading this junk in the zone chat, and the only way to stop seeing this scam spam is to turn off the entire zone chat and become antisocial. This problem is made 10 times worse by the fact that the devs keep taking measures to fight back against the scammers in a way that ruins it for all the honest folk. For example, because the scammers were scamming too much, they removed gifting from the game entirely. So the 99% of honest folk got their gifting privileges removed because of the 1% of players that are scammers. After a while they sort of added gifting back into the game but you need to go through some giant application process by raising a support ticket and they either accept or deny you based on unknown criteria. I got denied for my application to gift again, and I still don't know why. I actually got denied 3 times because I tried to reapply twice.

Trust me you don't want to get involved with this game, it will be lost time, and we humans don't live that long. If you want an MMO my recommendation is FF14. It's managed much better and the community is a million times nicer. They're a bit of a furry lot, but you can look past that when they're so damn helpful and positive

184299450.review:
Man, I really wanted to love ESO. I’m a huge Elder Scrolls fan – Skyrim? Classic. Oblivion? Chef’s kiss. Morrowind? Don’t even get me started. But this? ESO feels like they slapped Tamriel onto a grindy MMO framework and called it a day.

First off, the combat. Why does it feel like I’m smacking enemies with a pool noodle? No weight, no impact – just flailing and hoping numbers pop up on the screen. It’s like Skyrim’s combat got drunk and forgot how to work.

And the quests? Sure, some of the stories are cool, but man, so much filler. "Go here, collect this, kill five of those." Repeat. It’s like they ran out of ideas halfway through. I signed up to be the next Dragonborn, not Tamriel’s errand boy.

Also, let's talk about the cash shop. Yikes. They want me to pay for mounts, cosmetics, and even basic conveniences like crafting bag space? C'mon, Zenimax. I already paid for the game AND the expansions. Why am I being nickel-and-dimed like I’m in Tamriel’s sketchiest market?

Don’t even get me started on the performance. Laggy servers, random crashes – I thought my PC was dying, but nope, it’s just ESO being ESO.

To be fair, the world-building and exploration are kinda cool. But at the end of the day, ESO feels more like a chore than an adventure. If you’re looking for the next Skyrim, this ain’t it, chief.

5/10 – Play it if you love MMOs and don’t mind paying extra for everything. Otherwise, save your Septims.

184221669.review:
Adepte de MMORPG, je joue à WoW depuis 13 ans, je suis passé sur FF14 et pas mal de MMO en général, mais je n'avais pas encore testé TESO.

L'évolution de notre personnage, clé de voûte des MMO, se découpe en deux : 
- D'abord la partie ou on monte son perso au lvl 50, on y débloque des compétences en fonction de celles que l'on utilise. Plus on utilise un type de compétence, plus celle-ci augmente et nous propose de choix. C'est bien fichu parce que pour débloquer tout, il faut jouer de tout. Ca passe autant par les compétences de classe, que les guildes ou les armes utilisées.
Compétences que l'on peut choisir ou améliorer grâce à des points de compétences que l'on obtient soit en augmentant de niveau (jusqu'au lvl 50), soit en récupérant des cristaux (shards), soit en faisant certaines quêtes ou activités.

- Puis un système qui ressemble pas mal au Parangon de Diablo III, pour ceux à qui ça parle, ou l'on peut monter jusqu'au niveau 3000+, qui apporte un arbre de compétence plutôt fourni.


L'évolution dans le monde, elle, est assez similaire à ce que l'on connait, on navigue sur la map soit à pied, soit en monture (terrestre). Le bon point c'est que dès le début on possède des points de téléportation dans toutes les régions, ce qui nous permet d'aller ou l'on veut quand on veut. Les mobs s'adaptent à notre niveau (jusqu'au niveau de champion 160, ou le "vrai jeu commence"), rajoutant encore une couche sur le fait que l'on peut aller XP ou l'on souhaite. 

Il y a plusieurs types "d'instances", les Antres, qui sont des donjons relativement petits, avec un boss, généralement une quête, et une shard. Les Donjons publics, un peu plus complets avec plusieurs boss, des quêtes, etc. Si pour les deux premiers il est possible de croiser des joueurs, pour les derniers, les Donjons privés, vous ne croiserez personne, et il sera nécessaire d'y aller en groupe (ou en solo, avec mon Templier j'en ai solo un, donc c'est long mais "faisable")

Évidemment il existe une pléthore de quêtes, principales (de zone ou générales), secondaires, répétables.


Aussi, le système d'artisanat, il est très lié à l'évolution de notre personnage, en effet ces compétences se débloquent de la même manière que les compétences d'armes ou de classe. Plus vous faites d'artisanat, par exemple de Forge, plus vous gagnez de l'expérience dans cette pratique et plus vous pouvez dépenser vos points de compétences dedans. 
Il existe un nombre assez impressionnant de composants, liés soit à votre niveau de personnage, soit ensuite à votre niveau de champion. 

Pour finir, en ce qui concerne l'abonnement ESO+, il n'est pas essentiel, oui il ajoute de la "Quality of Life" avec l'inventaire d'artisanat, mais si vous jouez pour le plaisir sans chercher à looter tous les composants d'artisanats ce que vous voyez, il y a moyen de s'en passer. D'ailleurs la seule "vraie" raison de le prendre c'est clairement pour cet inventaire d'artisanat "infini", sans quoi ce qu'il apporte est franchement négligeable. Chacun y verra midi à sa porte, mais il me semble important de rappeler qu'un MMORPG coûte très cher à entretenir, et qu'il me semble normal que pour un géant comme TESO, cela soit proposé (et non "imposé" ...).

[hr][/hr]

Verdict, c'est un bonheur à jouer, très grosse vibe Skyrim, sans être exactement la même chose. Énormément de contenu, dont la plupart peut être fait en solo ce qui est un point appréciable, même dans un MMO. 
Beaucoup de zones à explorer, toujours un plaisir de retrouver les ambiances des zones comme dans les autres Elder Scrolls, même si les zones ne sont pas fidèles à 100%, l'ambiance y est.
Le gameplay est vif, le fait d'être en TPS avec un viseur me rappelle TERA, c'est bien fait. J'ai vite fait testé le PvP à l'écriture de ces lignes et c'était plutôt fun, très nerveux, quant à savoir pour l'équilibrage c'est un autre débat dans lequel je ne m'aventurerai pas, puisque je n'ai pas assez joué. 
J'ai pas vu de bugs majeurs durant mes 70 premières heures de jeu, vite fait un PNJ qui n'apparaissait pas dans une instance, je suis sortie et revenu et il était là.
C'est un MMO sur lequel j'aime aller pour être tranquille, exprimer ma "complétionnite aigüe", monter mes compétences de personnage, d’artisanat et profiter de l'ambiance en papillonnant pour récupérer des matériaux et autres collectibles.


tl;dr: MMORPG reprennant l'ambiance de Skyrim sans être Skyrim, grosse map à parcourir, presque tout est faisable avec un seul personnage. Possibilité de solo énormément de contenu, rendant le jeu très chill. Gameplay assez nerveux et propre. Abonnement facultatif, sauf pour les profils "complétionnistes".

184155249.review:
▎ The Elder Scrolls Online

The Elder Scrolls Online (ESO) — це MMORPG, розроблена компанією ZeniMax Online Studios і випущена в 2014 році. Гра дозволяє гравцям зануритись у великий та детально розроблений світ Тамріель, де вони можуть досліджувати, виконувати квести та взаємодіяти з іншими гравцями.

▎Сюжет та світ

У The Elder Scrolls Online дія відбувається за тисячу років до подій The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim. Гравці вивчають п'ять основних регіонів — Еландір, Ліланді, Домену, Алдмері, та імперії, що дозволяє отримати унікальний досвід в різних культурах і історіях. Сюжет охоплює численні події, конфлікти між фракціями і зустрічі з легендарними персонажами.

▎Геймплей та механіка

Гравці можуть вибрати свого персонажа з багатьох рас і класів, кожен з яких має свої унікальні здібності. Геймплей ESO включає в себе активну бойову систему, яка вимагає рефлексів та тактичного мислення. Гравці можуть також вступати в гільдії, брати участь у PvP-боях та досліджувати величезний світ.

Гра постійно оновлюється, виходять нові розширення і оновлення, що дозволяє підтримувати свіжість контенту та робить його більш привабливим для нових і давніх гравців.

▎Графіка та атмосфера

Атмосфера The Elder Scrolls Online наповнена елементами фентезі, з величними пейзажами, захоплюючими архітектурними формами та яскраво вираженими деталями. Графіка грає важливу роль у зануренні, і дизайн середовища сприяє широті вражень від дослідження світу.

▎Висновок

The Elder Scrolls Online пропонує багатий світ з глибокою історією та захоплюючим геймплеєм. Незалежно від того, чи ви є фанатом серії Elder Scrolls, чи просто шукаєте якісну MMORPG, ESO може стати чудовим вибором для тривалого та різноманітного ігрового досвіду.

When I first stumbled upon this game, it quickly took over my life. The development team consistently rolls out fresh updates, DLC, and exciting events that keep the community buzzing with activity. It's a dynamic environment that ensures there's always something new to explore and enjoy.

This game offers an expansive world where you can truly immerse yourself, featuring a wealth of activities such as PVP combat, PVP challenges, dungeons, and even the art of home decoration. The variety of options available in ESO is nothing short of incredible, making it easy to lose track of time as you dive into its many facets.

Additionally, the community surrounding this game is one of the most welcoming I've ever encountered. New players are embraced with open arms, and seasoned members are eager to share their knowledge, helping everyone grow stronger and wealthier in the game. 184000487.review:
The base game is a relatively fun experience, creating an Elder Scrolls character, using class skills to defeat mobs and complete quest to level up, but I am not keen on the chapter / dlc model.

If you buy the base game, you get the base game and the Morrowind chapter to keep for life, yes.

But the way the purchase model is set up is that you can buy Gold Road and get a bunch of extra chapters and zones to play in, but surprisingly, there is very little dlc that can be bought directly on steam. Why? Because ESO has an in-game purchase model where you spend real money to buy the in-game crown currency, and then you use those crowns to buy dlc, which ranges from cosmetics to extra zones and areas that aren't a part of the Gold Road bundle, such as Murkmire. The only way to get these things is to use the crowns, instead of buying them directly as steam dlc.

So you can buy the base game, you can buy the big Gold Road bundle, but the devs still want you to spend extra money on top of extra money for chapters and dlc packs just to play the in-game content, or buy the monthly subscription...

It's disappointing that developers would do this, and that long-time mmo players encourage this with their purchases and subscriptions...

183961273.review:
I haven't tried PVP nor joined a Group yet. But for Solo gaming and PVE play only, I can recommend this game at the current sale price with 67% discount for the [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/2662630/The_Elder_Scrolls_Online_Gold_Road/]The Elder Scrolls Online Deluxe Collection: Gold Road[/url].  The bundle includes all past 8 DLCs with some Deluxe items. The world is so huge so if you like exploration, this game is for you. There are varied Biomes with different creatures roaming around in their territories. Traveling is also easy when you learn how to use the Shrines and the Map. As the player discovers new locations and Shrines, the world slowly becomes more accessible. The combat system is great and player movement is quite fluid. I felt the difference every time I upgrade/downgrade my Character stats and gear. There are many game mechanics/systems aside from just fighting, item crafting, and housing.  There is also some sort of an archaeology system, spellcrafting, PVP, special events, and more.

Game's visual quality is still quite decent for this day and age... when I used the "DLAA" option in my Graphics Card. The audio quality is top-notch. The background music, the special effects timing and crispiness + loudness of them are right on and have contributed greatly to the feel of combat and when exploring the vast world.

What I don't like though is the [b]overpriced Crowns and the pricing of items in it's Store[/b]. They are just too expensive and unreachable for most folks. I suggest emulating the [b]Steam store[/b] and change their pricing model on these [b]Crown goods[/b] based on the regional location of the customer. Make it affordable to folks who like to buy sachets of shampoo's instead of a bottle, reloading of prepaid cellphone data instead of subscribing to a postpaid plan,  and so on... else just bundle all those Crown products and offer them as separate DLCs that usually go on sale and can be purchased by cash. By the way, the in-game currency system is also confusing for newbies but it works. There are Gold, Crowns, Gems, Event Tickets, Seals of Endeavor, and Writs if I remember correctly. They are used in different ways. But mostly to acquire more items and/or upgrades.

If you're looking for an MMORPG that can also work for solo PVE gaming aside from social gaming, [b]The Elder Scrolls Online: Gold Road Deluxe Collection[/b] might be for you. For players who complain about the game being too easy as they are masochist gamers who love the [i]Souls-like genre[/i], you can skip this title as you won't probably like it.  :-P  Game difficulty for this one is standard and the gear the player uses and his character stats will determine how a fight will go. It's a great combat system which the player has total control over. I just wish the Servers will be more stable so we can log in and play anytime we want. 

Lastly, please be informed that this [b]10 year old game[/b] has accumulated a huge file size and so downloading may take time before you can play especially if your Internet access is slow. Upon checking my Steam directory for this game, it uses nearly [b]140 GB[/b]. That's nearly three times the size of [b]The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt - Complete Edition[/b].
